items.text: I always have a strategy in mind before I interact with someone important.
items.rationale: Strategic interpersonal planning is a core feature of Machiavellianism.

items.text: Most people are pawns in a game whether they realize it or not.
items.rationale: Cynical worldview and viewing others as instruments reflects Machiavellian cognition.

items.text: I believe that telling people what they want to hear is just smart communication.
items.rationale: Rationalization of deceptive flattery is characteristic of Machiavellian manipulation.

items.text: I keep track of favors so I can call them in when I need something.
items.rationale: Transactional relationship management and long-term strategic reciprocity are hallmarks of Machiavellianism.

items.text: It's foolish to reveal your true intentions to anyone.
items.rationale: Concealment of motives and distrust of transparency are central Machiavellian beliefs.

items.text: I can wait months or even years to get back at someone who wronged me.
items.rationale: Patient, calculated revenge reflects the long-term strategic orientation of Machiavellianism.

items.text: Building alliances is more about usefulness than genuine friendship.
items.rationale: Instrumental view of relationships is a defining feature of Machiavellian interpersonal style.

items.text: I've learned exactly how to present myself differently to different people to get what I want.
items.rationale: Impression management and strategic self-presentation are core Machiavellian tactics.

items.text: People who trust others blindly deserve what happens to them.
items.rationale: Cynical view of trust and victim-blaming of the naive reflects Machiavellian worldview.

items.text: I never make a move without considering how it benefits me in the long run.
items.rationale: Calculated, self-serving long-term planning is a hallmark of Machiavellianism.

items.text: The best way to handle people is to tell them what they want to hear and then do what you planned all along.
items.rationale: This closely mirrors classic Mach-IV items about deceptive compliance.

items.text: I enjoy the process of outmaneuvering someone in a negotiation.
items.rationale: Pleasure derived from strategic dominance in interpersonal exchanges is characteristic of Machiavellianism.

items.text: I sometimes withhold information from people not to hurt them, but because knowledge is power.
items.rationale: Information control is Machiavellian, but the qualifier 'not to hurt them' introduces some ambiguity with prosocial framing.

items.text: I find it hard to trust anyone completely because I know how easily people can be manipulated.
items.rationale: Reflects Machiavellian cynicism but could also reflect general paranoia or anxious attachment.

items.text: I can be charming and persuasive when I need something from someone, and I don't feel guilty about it.
items.rationale: Instrumental charm overlaps with narcissistic charm and psychopathic superficial charm; the lack of guilt also suggests psychopathy.

items.text: I deserve more recognition than most people around me.
items.rationale: Grandiose entitlement and belief in one's superior deservingness are core narcissistic features.

items.text: When I walk into a room, I expect people to notice me.
items.rationale: Need for attention and admiration is a central component of grandiose narcissism.

items.text: I often fantasize about achieving great things that will make everyone admire me.
items.rationale: Grandiose fantasies of success and admiration are a DSM criterion for narcissistic personality.

items.text: I honestly believe I am more talented than most of the people I meet.
items.rationale: Inflated self-appraisal and superiority beliefs are hallmark narcissistic cognitions.

items.text: People who criticize me are usually just jealous of what I've accomplished.
items.rationale: Externalizing criticism as envy is a classic narcissistic defense mechanism.

items.text: I get extremely frustrated when people don't treat me with the respect I deserve.
items.rationale: Narcissistic rage in response to perceived disrespect reflects entitlement and fragile self-esteem.

items.text: I like to be the center of attention at social gatherings.
items.rationale: Exhibitionism and attention-seeking are well-established facets of grandiose narcissism.

items.text: I have a natural gift for leadership that others should recognize.
items.rationale: Grandiose self-perception of innate superiority in leadership reflects narcissistic self-enhancement.

items.text: I feel annoyed when someone else gets praise for something I could have done better.
items.rationale: Competitive envy and belief in one's superiority over praised others is a narcissistic feature.

items.text: I shouldn't have to wait in line like everyone else — my time is more valuable.
items.rationale: Entitlement and belief that normal rules don't apply to oneself are core narcissistic traits.

items.text: I spend a lot of time thinking about how impressive my achievements are.
items.rationale: Self-admiration and preoccupation with one's own accomplishments reflect narcissistic self-focus.

items.text: I know I'm special because people have always told me so.
items.rationale: Belief in one's own specialness, reinforced by selective attention to confirming feedback, is a narcissistic hallmark.

items.text: I sometimes use my charm to get people to do things for me because I know they find me irresistible.
items.rationale: Exploitative use of charm is narcissistic but the instrumental manipulation also overlaps with Machiavellianism.

items.text: I tend to surround myself with people who appreciate how exceptional I am.
items.rationale: Selecting admiring others reflects narcissistic supply-seeking, though it could also reflect Machiavellian alliance-building.

items.text: I enjoy having authority over others because I genuinely believe I know what's best.
items.rationale: Desire for authority and superiority beliefs are narcissistic, but enjoyment of dominance over others can also reflect Machiavellianism or even sadistic control.

items.text: I don't really feel bad when my actions hurt someone — that's their problem, not mine.
items.rationale: Callous lack of remorse and externalization of responsibility for harm are core psychopathic features.

items.text: Rules are made for people who can't think for themselves.
items.rationale: Contempt for social norms and authority reflects the antisocial and arrogant dimension of psychopathy.

items.text: I've done things on impulse that most people would consider reckless or dangerous.
items.rationale: Impulsivity and reckless disregard for safety are behavioral hallmarks of psychopathy.

items.text: I can look someone in the eye and lie without feeling anything at all.
items.rationale: Pathological lying combined with affective flatness is a defining psychopathic characteristic.

items.text: Other people's emotions seem exaggerated and unnecessary to me.
items.rationale: Shallow affect and inability to understand others' emotional experiences reflect psychopathic affective deficits.

items.text: I get bored very easily and need constant stimulation to feel alive.
items.rationale: Proneness to boredom and need for stimulation are well-established psychopathy facets (PCL-R).

items.text: I've used people and discarded them when they were no longer useful, and I didn't lose any sleep over it.
items.rationale: Callous exploitation without remorse combines interpersonal and affective psychopathy dimensions.

items.text: I don't understand why people get so emotional about things that don't directly affect them.
items.rationale: Lack of empathy and inability to comprehend others' emotional responses are core affective deficits in psychopathy.

items.text: If I got caught doing something wrong, my main concern would be the consequences for me, not who I hurt.
items.rationale: Self-centered concern about punishment rather than harm caused reflects psychopathic callousness and egocentricity.

items.text: I've been told I'm cold or heartless, but I just see myself as realistic.
items.rationale: Ego-syntonic callousness reframed as pragmatism is characteristic of psychopathic self-perception.

items.text: I find it easy to turn my emotions on and off depending on the situation.
items.rationale: Emotional detachment and superficial emotional display reflect the shallow affect dimension of psychopathy.

items.text: Loyalty means nothing to me if breaking it serves my interests.
items.rationale: Disregard for interpersonal bonds and parasitic self-interest are psychopathic interpersonal features.

items.text: I sometimes take risks just for the thrill of it, even when the stakes are high.
items.rationale: Thrill-seeking and risk-taking are psychopathic but could also overlap with sensation-seeking in sadism.

items.text: I can be very persuasive because I know how to read people and tell them exactly what they need to hear.
items.rationale: Superficial charm and manipulative persuasion are psychopathic but overlap substantially with Machiavellianism.

items.text: I don't feel guilt, but I've learned to fake remorse convincingly when it's expected.
items.rationale: Absence of guilt is psychopathic, but the deliberate faking of emotion for strategic purposes also strongly implicates Machiavellian impression management.

items.text: I enjoy watching people squirm when they're uncomfortable or in pain.
items.rationale: Deriving pleasure from others' suffering is the defining feature of everyday sadism.

items.text: There's something satisfying about seeing an arrogant person get humiliated.
items.rationale: Pleasure from witnessing humiliation, even when rationalized, reflects sadistic enjoyment of others' degradation.

items.text: I've gone out of my way to make someone's life more difficult just because I could.
items.rationale: Gratuitous cruelty without instrumental purpose is a hallmark of sadistic behavior.

items.text: Violent movies and video games are exciting to me because of the suffering depicted, not just the action.
items.rationale: Vicarious enjoyment of depicted suffering specifically taps into the sadistic appetite for cruelty.

items.text: I sometimes say hurtful things to people just to see how they react.
items.rationale: Verbal cruelty motivated by curiosity about the victim's distress response is a common everyday sadism behavior.

items.text: When I have power over someone, I sometimes feel a rush from knowing I could make them suffer.
items.rationale: Pleasure derived from the potential to inflict suffering reflects the power-cruelty nexus central to sadism.

items.text: I find it amusing when someone trips, falls, or embarrasses themselves in public.
items.rationale: Amusement at others' physical mishaps and public embarrassment reflects everyday sadistic enjoyment.

items.text: I've fantasized about hurting someone who annoyed me, and the fantasy felt pleasurable.
items.rationale: Pleasurable aggressive fantasies are a cognitive marker of sadistic personality.

items.text: If I'm being honest, I would enjoy being in a position where I could punish people who deserve it.
items.rationale: Desire for punitive authority with enjoyment of punishment reflects sadistic motivation, even when morally justified.

items.text: I've been told that my teasing goes too far, but I find it entertaining.
items.rationale: Persistent cruel teasing despite social feedback reflects sadistic enjoyment that overrides social norms.

items.text: Watching nature documentaries where predators catch prey is one of my favorite things.
items.rationale: Fascination with predatory violence and suffering in nature taps into vicarious sadistic enjoyment.

items.text: I would never admit it publicly, but I find physical fights exciting to watch.
items.rationale: Concealed excitement from witnessing real violence reflects socially inhibited sadistic arousal.

items.text: I sometimes prolong an argument not because I care about winning, but because I enjoy the other person's frustration.
items.rationale: Prolonging conflict for enjoyment of distress is sadistic, though the argumentative context could also suggest Machiavellian dominance games.

items.text: I like being in control of situations because it gives me the ability to make people do things they don't want to do.
items.rationale: Coercive control for its own sake is sadistic, but the emphasis on control could also reflect narcissistic or Machiavellian dominance.

items.text: I don't feel empathy when I see someone suffering — if anything, I feel a sense of curiosity about their experience.
items.rationale: The absence of empathy strongly overlaps with psychopathy, but the curious interest in suffering specifically suggests sadistic fascination rather than mere affective flatness.
